intro: Haplopappus gummiferus, commonly known as the gumweed, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive leaf structure. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is known for its sticky, resinous secretions. Its leaves are usually narrow and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and yellowish. Haplopappus gummiferus plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and habitat for small insects.
